_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

- Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Michigan Milk Producers Association (MMPA) is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with our regulated processes. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible accidental releases of regulated substances. However, if such an accidental release does occur, MMPA coordinates with off-site emergency response support.


- The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

Presently ammonia  (Anhydrous) is the only RMP regulated substance present at this facility in a threshold quantity.  The ammonia system at the Michigan Milk Producers Association consists primarily of vessels, compressors, condensers, evaporators and associated piping. The majority of the equipment is located inside the engine room. The system is a closed loop refrigeration system similar to a residential refrigerator. There are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia.

The maximum intended inventory of ammonia at the MMPA facility is approximately 22,000 pounds (~4,272 gallons at 60ÂºF) within one refrigeration system. Typical operating conditions range from approximately 50 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 165 psig on the high side.

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously.  Compressors and condensers cycle on and off to comply with system demand during operation.  The ammonia refrigeration system provides cooling for cold storage and chilling of milk products.  

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver to the Glycol Chiller Accumulators, Surge Drums (SD1-SD5), Surge Vessels (SV1-SV7, SV11, SV12-SV14, SV16), Cooler Room Evaporators, and th

e Buttermilk Heat Exchanger. Prior to entering each vessel, the high pressure liquid ammonia experiences a pressure drop through hand expansion valves.  This drop in pressure induces a portion of the ammonia to flash, hence lowering the liquid's pressure/temperature.  A small supply of high pressure liquid is also reserved for the FES/Frick Compressors for oil cooling. 

The Glycol Chiller Accumulators, Surge Drums, and Surge Vessels maintain a reservoir of liquid ammonia, which is used to provide low pressure liquid to their respective heat exchangers.  The Glycol Chiller Accumulators provide low pressure liquid to the Glycol Chiller Evaporators.  Surge drums SD1 and SD2 provide low pressure liquid to Plate Chillers PC1 and PC2.  Surge drums SD3 and SD4 provide low pressure liquid to the two Ice Builders.  Surge Drum SD5 provides low pressure liquid to Plate Chiller PC3.  The Surge Vessels provide low pressure liquid to the heating jacket surrounding each of the Cream Tanks.  Suction is then returned from these heat exchangers back to their associated vessels. 

Suction from the Glycol Chiller Accumulators, Surge Drums, Surge Vessels, Buttermilk Heat Exchanger, and the Cooler Room Evaporators is routed to a common suction header and sent to the Suction Accumulator. Liquid, which accumulates in the Suction Accumulator, is transferred back to the High Pressure Receiver via a dump trap.  Once the level in the dump trap reaches the float switch, the transfer cycle begins and liquid ammonia is sent back to the high pressure receiver.  

The ammonia/oil mixture from the oil pots associated with the Surge Vessels and the Suction Accumulator is collected in the Oil Accumulator. The Oil Accumulator is a vessel containing a heating element, which supplies heat to boil the liquid ammonia away from the oil. The ammonia suction from the top of the vessel is drawn by the Pump Out Compressor and the discharge is sent to the condenser via the high stage discharge line.  

Suction

from the Suction Accumulator is drawn off by the compressors, which discharge through a common header to the condenser where the high pressure ammonia vapor is condensed to a high pressure liquid and then drained back to the High Pressure Receiver. The high pressure vapor is condensed by discharging latent heat in the ammonia to the atmosphere using sprayed water and fans. 


- The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Michigan Milk Producers Association has taken all necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  Michigan Milk Producers Association is also subject to the OSHA PSM Standard under 29 CFR 1910.119, as well as the EPCRA Section 302 and 311/312 notification/reporting requirements. The facility also maintains a contract with a professional refrigeration service firm to conduct preventative maintenance and any necessary repairs.

Ammonia detectors are strategically located in the Engine Room and the facility. In case of ammonia detection, visible and audible alarms will activate at the facility and at the computer system.

In the event of a power failure, ammonia operations would automatically shut-down (solenoid valves close, compressors shut-down, condenser fans and water pumps shut-down, evaporator fans shut-down, etc.), thereby limiting the possibility of any ammonia releases. 

The system also incorporates a pressure relief system. In the event of over-pressurization, vessels will vent to atmosphere until the system pressure decreases sufficiently to reseat the valves. This mechanism prevents vessels from rupturing in case they become over pressurized.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion. The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to a household refrigerator. The refrigeration

system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases. Any leaks are noted during daily walk-throughs and repaired immediately.


- Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental ammonia releases at the Michigan Milk Producers Association facility within the last five years. (January 2006 to January 2010)


- Emergency Action Plan

Michigan Milk Producers Association current Emergency Action Plan focuses on evacuation of the facility in the event of an ammonia emergency, with the assistance from local emergency response agencies performing rescue, firefighting, first-aid, medical treatment, and other response functions. The facility maintains a written Emergency Action Plan to document specific procedures to be implemented in the event of various emergencies, including ammonia release. The Plan includes procedures for facility evacuation, as well as for notification to the local emergency response agencies, which are responsible for notifying the public. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the facility that would require modified procedures.

To plan for an ammonia release with off-site effects, Michigan Milk Producers Association Emergency Action Plan includes procedures/equipment to mitigate the release, procedures to inform local response agencies, transportation maps for response agencies, evacuation route maps, and procedures for public communication.

In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off site effects, the general public will be notified by on-site staff and off-site governmental officials.


- Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Michigan Milk Producers Association's aim is to provide a professional service as efficiently as possible while minimizing the use of toxic materials wherever and whenever prudent.  In this effort our highest priority will be the proactive pursuit of cost-effective process changes that reduce or eliminate the use and/or generation of hazardous
toxics at the endpoint of service.  Where hazardous toxics cannot be eliminated, improving controls to handle these substances will be explored and implemented wherever possible.
